title: Psychosocial determinants of health, chronic disease and mortality
abstractText:
Maintaining health with increasing age is influenced not only by personal circumstances and lifestyle choices, but by social experience, psychological characteristics and emotional health.
We are studying the way in which emotions, including anxiety, depression, hostility or stress and the ability to cope with them, are linked with physical health and well-being.
Over 20,000 participants in the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer, a study of men and women living in Norfolk (UK), have completed blood tests and provided information about their diet, lifestyles, emotional health, personal and social resources together with details of their experience of stress in their lives.
Through this information, we hope to increase understanding of the way in which emotions are linked to health. Recent work, for example has suggested that a personâ€˜s ability to cope with stress may reduce their risk of having a stroke by around a quarter.
We hope that the knowledge gained in this research will strengthen the scientific evidence linking social and psychological factors with medical outcomes including cancer and heart disease, and also inform health promotion, health prevention and approaches to improve public health.
